quote: The gymnast?
She found it relaxing.
Do you?
Actually, it's giving me a headache.
What about Julian, can't he work with Garak?
Julian's a good physician, but he's not a counselor -- (before she can point it out) -- or even an assistant counselor. And besides, he doesn't have eight lifetimes of experience under his belt.
I bet he doesn't stand on his head for no reason, either.
You can do this, old man. I know you can.
All right. I'll try. I just wish I had as much confidence in me as you do.
So what do you think?
About what?
About her.
Who?
Dax.
Ezri? She seems... nice.
Meaning what?
Meaning... nice.
Come on, Doctor. I know the way you felt about Jadzia.
She's not Jadzia.
She's the next best thing. So are you interested?
Sounds to me like you're the one who's interested.
It's not every day you get a second chance with a woman.
She's not the same woman.
She's still Dax, isn't she?
More or less.
That's good enough for me. Ready for a little competition?
You're insane.
And you... are going to lose.
Am I interrupting?
You must be Ezri Dax. The captain told me you'd be dropping by to... "counsel" me.
Is that all right?
That depends on what's involved. You see, I'm a very private person.
I understand. So is it helping?
The sewing. Is it making you feel better?
Thankfully, yes. In fact --
(before he can continue) You're lucky, nothing helps me.
Are you claustrophobic, too?
What makes you say that?
You just said --
(realizing the misunderstanding) No, I get spacesick. Ever since I was joined. I'm very sensitive to motion. I can even feel the station spinning.
Really?
It's because of what happened to Torias. He died in a shuttle accident.
Why would that make you spacesick?
Because I blame myself for what happened.
You were piloting?
Yes. No. Depends on how you look at it. Torias was my fifth host. Didn't I say that?
No.
Well, he was. And I think the reason his death has stayed with me for so long is that I just can't seem to forgive him for getting himself killed.
But you said it was an accident. If he wasn't to blame, then you're not to blame, either.
I know. But somehow I can't help punishing myself for it.
By getting spacesick.
Exactly.
Don't take this the wrong way, but it sounds to me like you're the one that needs to see a counselor.
You're probably right. But I didn't come here to talk about my problems.
Do you remember anything traumatic happening to you when you were young -- something that involved getting trapped in a confined space.
If I'd been that careless, my father would've left me there to teach me a lesson.
Sounds like he was strict.
He didn't get to be the head of the Obsidian Order without a sense of... discipline.
Did he discipline you?
He'd punish me when I misbehaved. What father wouldn't?
Did your mother approve of his punishments?
Not that it mattered. She didn't have a key to the closet.
The closet?
My father used to lock me in when I misbehaved.
(why didn't you tell me?) Garak, I asked you if you'd ever been trapped in a confined space when you were young.
I wasn't trapped. I knew he'd let me out when I learned my lesson.
Learned your lesson?
(tugging at his collar) I could be very stubborn.
That's not the point. Nothing a child could do justifies locking him in a closet.
No wonder you get claustrophobic. It's just like me getting spacesick. We're both punishing ourselves for things that weren't our fault.
Are you saying that if I can stop blaming myself, my claustrophobia will just disappear?
Not overnight, but letting go of all this misplaced guilt would be a good start.
(dabbing his forehead) Well, I'll certainly give your advice some thought.
Are you all right?
To tell you the truth, I'm starting to feel a little claustrophobic.
Probably because we've been talking about it. Actually, I'm starting to feel a little spacesick myself.
If you don't mind, I think I'll get back to my sewing.
Good idea.
(picking up his seamer) Thank you for coming by.
My pleasure...
Hello, Worf.
Ensign.
Ensign? That's all you have to say to me?
What more is there to say?
I was your wife.
You are not Jadzia. She died and went to Sto-vo-kor. I do not know you, nor do I wish to.
Come in.
Dax... ?
Do you think the chief could adjust the inertial dampers so the station would spin a little slower?
I don't know. Why?
Never mind. To what do I owe the pleasure?
I'm not going to say I told you so, but Garak dropped by Odo's office this morning. He wanted to pick up the latest Cardassian transmissions for decoding.
Really?
Looks like his claustrophobia is under control.
I guess our talk must've helped...
Told you so.
I thought you said you weren't going to say that.
Couldn't resist.
You all right?
I talked with Worf.
How'd it go?
He doesn't want to have anything to do with me.
Maybe I should have a talk with him.
Absolutely not. You intimidate him.
Me?
Don't tell him I told you.
(trying to get used to the idea) I intimidate Worf.
You like that, don't you?
Of course not.
Come on. I've been a man, I know.
Look, we're not talking about me and Worf, we're talking about you and Worf. Now, I sympathize with what he's going through, but as far as I'm concerned, you have as much right to be here as he does.
(sensing he's taking this somewhere) What are you getting at, Benjamin?
This war hasn't been good for morale around here. I've been thinking the station could use a counselor. I can't think of anyone better suited for the job.
Thanks for saying that. But even if Worf wasn't an issue, I'm still just an assistant counselor.
I took the liberty of contacting Starfleet Medical. They're willing to waive the rest of your training and give you a commission as a full counselor with the rank of lieutenant.
How'd you talk them into that?
I asked them what they thought you were going to learn in the next few months --
That I haven't already learned in the last three hundred years.
They saw my point. I wish you would, too.
Benjamin, it means a lot to know that you want me to stay. But I can't.
Because of Worf...
Mostly.
Just say the word, and I'll go intimidate him for you.
You'd like that, wouldn't you?
I'danian spice pudding. No, cancel that. I'll have kilm steak, rare. No, Tobin was a vegetarian. Give me...
Two Fanalian toddys, hot.
How'd you know?
Lucky guess.
Join me?
Sure.
So... here we are.
What was that?
What was what?
That look.
(unsure if he should tell her) This might be the last thing you want to hear right now... but you have Jadzia's eyes. I shouldn't have said anything.
Don't flirt with me, Julian. Please.
I'm not.
I remember the way you used to flirt with Jadzia.
It was just an observation.
Good. Because I'm not like her. She knew how to handle it. (come to think of it) In fact, she enjoyed it.
Really?
You didn't know?
Well, I suspected...
You can be very charming. (knowing this will mean a lot to him) And you want to know something? If Worf hadn't come along, it would've been you...
You really miss her, don't you?
I suppose I always will... but somehow, talking to you seems to help.
Deputy Talpet to Doctor Bashir.
Go ahead.
We have a medical emergency in Airlock Seven. It's Garak, sir.
On my way.
Open it! Let me out!
Breathe in...
And out. (repeating the process) In... and out. Better?
(trying to get him to take in the view) Beautiful, isn't it? Look at that sky. It just goes on and on.
No, it doesn't. It's an illusion. There's a holosuite wall not ten meters in front of us.
But you can't see it.
I can feel it.
We could call up another program.
I can't believe the way I humiliated myself back there. (trying to make sense of what he did) I just wanted to... get out. I couldn't breathe.
If you were looking for fresh air, you were knocking on the wrong door.

(trying to rally himself) I have to get this situation under control. If I don't, I'm going to be forced to leave the station. Where would I go? I can't go back to Cardassia... I doubt I'd be welcome on Bajor...
You're not going to have to leave the station. I'll talk to Quark and tell him to make this holosuite available to you twenty- six hours a day.
Whenever you feel like walking out the nearest airlock, you can come here instead.
It's going to be all right we're going to get this under control. I promise.
If you don't mind, I'd like to sit here and be alone for a while.
I'll check in on you later.
Ow!
Hold still. I think I've got something.
I knew it. Never get a Tympanic Tickle from an amateur.
Tympanic Tickle... ? (before Quark can explain) Never mind. I don't want to know. Sit tight. I'm going to get you an antibiotic.
We need to talk.
About what?
Do not toy with me, Doctor. I know how you felt about Jadzia.
Worf, that was a long time ago.
I saw you with her.
With Jadzia?
You know who I'm talking about.
You've got it all wrong.
Stay away from her.
Now wait just a minute.
You have no right to tell me who I can be friends with.
If you dishonor Jadzia's memory, you will regret it.
That goes for you too, Ferengi.
What did I do... ?
Uh-oh. Keep an eye out for Worf.
Hi, Quark. Can I have a cup of coffee?
(trying to get rid of her) Why would you want to pay me for coffee when you can get it for free at the Replimat?
Ah. Oh.
Can I have a cup of coffee, please? I want to get back up to Garak.
He's gone. He left about an hour ago.
(surprised and concerned) Where'd he go?
I don't know. Well, don't just stand there. Go find him.
Garak... ?
I thought you were going to stay in the holosuite for a while.

I got tired of looking at a fake landscape and pretending I was outside. Work is the answer. My father always used to say that a person should throw themselves into their work. Do your chores, Elim. I told you to do your chores.
And if you didn't? What would he do to you?
Oh, no. Don't start. Spare me your insipid psychobabble. I'm not some quivering neurotic who feels sorry for himself because his daddy wasn't nice to him. You couldn't begin to understand me.
I'd like to try.
I'm sure you would. You'd like nothing more than to pry into my personal affairs.

Well, I'm not interested in dissecting my childhood... all I want is to free my people from the Dominion. I don't need someone to come in here and hold my hand, I need someone who can help me get back to work. And you, my dear, aren't up to the task.

Look at you. You're pathetic. A confused child trying to live up to the legacy left by her predecessors. You're not worthy of the name Dax. I knew Jadzia -- she was vital -- alive. She owned herself. But you -- you don't even know who you are. How dare you presume to help me? You can't even help yourself.
Now, get out of here. Before I say something unkind.
What's this all about?
What does it look like? I'm resigning from Starfleet.
Why?
Because I can't do my job. Garak's right -- how can I help other people when I can't even help myself?
I know this has been a hard time for you, old man --
Don't call me that! I'm not the old man. I'm not Curzon. Or Jadzia.
No, you're Ezri. Ezri Dax. You've been given eight lifetimes worth of experience -- I know it's confusing right now, but in time you'll see it's a wonderful gift.
It's a gift I don't deserve.
If that's the way you feel, then go back to Trill. Talk to the Symbiosis Commission -- maybe you can convince them to take the symbiont out of you.
I wish they could. But removing the symbiont would kill me, you know that.

If you're leaving Starfleet, you're going to have to find something to do. Maybe you could be one of those people who takes care of the symbiont pools? It's quiet in those caves. No one around, no one expecting great things from you. You could spend the rest of your life underground, in the dark, stirring mud. Eighty or ninety years of that might be just what you need. And as for Dax? That symbiont's had eight amazing lives -- so what if the ninth is a waste?
Stop it, Benjamin. I thought you of all people would understand--
I do understand. You were right. You don't deserve the Dax symbiont. And frankly, you don't deserve to wear that uniform.
I'll pass this on to Starfleet Command. Dismissed.
Yes.
Not again.
Compliments of Doctor Bashir.
He sent you here?
It was my idea. Now, if you want to skip the drinking and get right down to talking, I'm game.
(getting back to his bat'leth) What do you wish to discuss?
Julian swears there's nothing going on between him and Ezri. There's no reason for you to be jealous.
This has nothing to do with jealousy. I know the Doctor cared for Jadzia. But this woman is not Jadzia. And treating her as if she were dishonors her memory.
No, treating Ezri like a stranger dishonors Jadzia's memory.
It doesn't make sense. She is not Jadzia, yet she is. How can I honor the memory of the woman I loved when she's not really dead?
I don't have an answer for you, Worf. But let me ask you this: how do you think Jadzia would've wanted you to treat Ezri?
There is no way to know.
Yes, there is. And the person who can tell you is the person you've been avoiding ever since she got here.
I didn't think you'd darken my doorstep again.
I just wanted to say I'm sorry. I wish I'd been able to help you.
So do I.
Well, don't worry. I won't be bothering you anymore. I'm leaving in the morning.
Yes, I heard the Destiny was going to be arriving tomorrow.
They're putting in for supplies before they head to the front. But I won't be going with them. I've decided to go back to Trill.
How nice for you.
(thinking he might be interested) Actually, the Destiny's going to join the Seventh Fleet at Kalandra.
Kalandra?
Those transmissions you decoded last week must've convinced Starfleet that it's a good place to launch a new offensive.
Yes... the transmissions did indicate it was somewhat vulnerable.
If the offensive goes well, Starfleet will have you to thank for it.
(tugging at his collar) That's very gratifying...
I just thought you should know...
Are you all right?
Of course I'm all right. That's very good news about Kalandra.
Let's just hope it goes well. The Cardassians will put up a strong fight.
Indeed they will. But in the end, they'll lose.
How can you be so sure?
Because they won't be expecting an attack. They have no idea I broke their code.
All those Cardassians are going to die... because of me...
I suppose that's one way to look at it.
What other way is there?
That by helping to end the war, you're saving lives.
Who will I be saving -- Humans, Klingons, Romulans?
And Cardassians.
No, not Cardassians. They're going to fight to the end. The Dominion will see to that.
Don't you see? I wanted to believe I was helping my people, liberating them, but all I've done is pave the way for their annihilation. I'm a traitor! I've betrayed -- -- every... -- thing...
Dax to Infirmary, I need a medical team.
How are you feeling?
Well... I'm breathing a lot better than I was.
At least we found out what's been triggering these claustrophobic attacks you've been having.

(trying to make sense of it) When I first agreed to help Starfleet, I was convinced that it was the right thing to do. I didn't allow myself to doubt it, even for a moment. I never realized how much it was gnawing away at me. I suppose I was looking for a way out... and the claustrophobia gave me an excuse to stop fighting against my people.
Now that you know that, what are you going to do?
Get back to work. What else can I do? The Dominion has to be stopped. Even if it means the destruction of Cardassia.
The captain's going to be glad to hear you're back on the job.
He has you to thank for it. And so do I.
So what about you? Are you still planning on going back to Trill?
No. I'm going to stay in Starfleet.
I'm sure the captain will be glad to hear that, too.
My resignation --
(re: the PADD in his hand) Now what?
It's my request to be reinstated into Starfleet.
I can't send this to Starfleet Command.
Why not?
Because I never sent in your resignation.
I had a feeling you didn't mean all those things you said to me. You were just trying to rattle my cage.
You've done it to me often enough. I'm glad it worked.
Garak's asked that the latest Cardassian transmissions be sent to the Infirmary. Well done.
Thanks. Somehow I thought you'd be happier to hear I'm staying in Starfleet.
I guess I'd be happier if you were staying here at D.S. Nine.
Me, too. But you know I can't.
I hope Captain Raymer knows how lucky she is. She's getting a hell of a counselor.
Yes.
May I come in?
Of course.
I understand that you are leaving in the morning.
That's right.
I am not certain that I have treated you the way Jadzia would've wanted me to.
You'll get no argument from me there.
I loved her with all my heart.
And she loved you...
Part of me is glad to know that she is not gone forever... but even so, in some ways it would be easier if she were.
I know.
I have heard that the captain has offered you a position as station counselor. I would not want you to decline on my account.
Worf, I can't stay. I couldn't do that to you.
Do you wish to stay?
Very much.
Then do. Jadzia would not have wanted you to leave because of me.
Thank you.
It will be a long time before I can accept that I have lost her. Until then...
You need some breathing room. I understand.
Congratulations, lieutenant.
I want you to take a good look around. Because you've just agreed to take responsibility for the mental health of everyone in this room.
You've got your work cut out for you.
It's a good thing they made you a lieutenant. I can't see taking advice from an ensign.
Since when do you take advice from anyone?
Why don't you join us for dinner tonight?
I don't want to put you out.
Please come. It'll take the pressure off me. He just sits there and counts how many times I chew.
I'll be there.
She is cute.
She's also about three hundred years too old for you.
I took the liberty of putting together a plate for you.
Thanks, Quark. Worf's not here, is he?
Good question.
Congratulations, quite a crowd.
I hope it's not making you uncomfortable.
Not at all.
I need you to explain something to someone.
Morn, it's me. Dax.
I'm truly impressed.

And I'm not easily impressed. In all my years as proprietor of Quark's Bar, Grill, Gaming House and Holosuite Arcade, I have never seen such a glowing employee performance report. I mean look at this --
-- in three months, no customer has filed a single complaint against you. You haven't spilled a drink or mixed up a food order or shortchanged a bill.
I take my job very seriously.
And yet you always manage to wear a friendly smile.
That's because I like my work. I'm happy to be here.
It shows. The customers love you, your fellow dabo girls love you -- even the Ferengi waiters sing your praises. And you know why? Because you're nice.
I try to be.
You're nice to the customers, to the dabo girls, to the Ferengi waiters. You're nice to everyone. Almost everyone.
You mean I've offended someone?
Look closely, Aluura. Can't you see the pain in my eyes?
But I'm always nice to you.
I think you could be nicer.
How much nicer?
"Oo-mox for Fun and Profit."
It's a quick read.
Oh. You want me to be "nice."
Let's face it. The customers, the dabo girls, the Ferengi waiters... they didn't hire you. And they can't fire you.
Brother! We need to talk.
Go away. I'm in the middle of a meeting.
But it's important.
So's the meeting.
It's about our mother.
How many times have I told you not to mention Moogie when I'm... ... you know, working.
Sorry. But I tried contacting her this morning, and I couldn't get through.
She's probably off "visiting" the Grand Nagus.
I tried the Tower of Commerce. There was no answer there either.
They're probably on vacation. Now leave me alone, I'm trying to concentrate.
Brother, you don't understand. I can't get a hold of anyone on Ferenginar. Not Cousin Gaila, not Lek... I tell you, something's very wrong.
We'll continue this later. In the meantime, you've got some reading to do.
Hello, Aluura. Good book.
Let's go.
She's so nice.
We'll see.
A Dominion invasion of Ferenginar?
Think of the terrible repercussions to the Alpha Quadrant.
I can't think of any.
How could the Dominion invade Ferenginar without first conquering the systems surrounding it like Clarus and Irtok?
Brother, did you hear that? They've captured Irtok as well.
That's not what I said.
There are no reports of Dominion activity anywhere near that sector.
Then why can't we get through to Ferenginar?
Moogie, the Nagus, Cousin Gaila...
... they're all dead.
We don't know that. But something's definitely wrong on Ferenginar.
We'll see what we can find out.
Captain, a Ferengi ship is approaching the station and requesting permission to dock. It's Grand Nagus Zek... ... and your mother's with him.
They're alive! Nice work.
Quark! Rom!
It's good to see you boys.
It's good to see you, too, Nagus.
Moogie! I was so worried...
You're a good son.
I was worried, too.
And you're a good liar.
Moogie... do you think it's a good idea to be wearing clothes in public?
He's right. What if one of my Ferengi waiters sees you?
I hope they do. Tell them, Zekkie.
No, you go right ahead, my dear.
It should really come from you.
Would somebody please tell me what's going on?
It's one of those good-news-bad- news type of things... Give them the good news first.
If you insist. Three days ago, I added a new amendment to the Ferengi Bill of Opportunities giving females the right to wear clothes.
In public?
Anywhere we want.

That can't be the good news. If Ferengi females can wear clothes in public, they can leave their homes. If they can leave their homes, they can go to work. If they can go to work, they can make profit.
What's the matter, Quark? Afraid of a little competition?
You're sure that's the good news?
It sounds good to me.
Now do you see why I like him best?
Face it, Quark. It's good business. For thousands of years, Ferenginar has allowed a valuable resource to go to waste.
Females? A valuable resource?
They make up fifty-three point five percent of the population and contribute virtually nothing to the gross planetary income. I say it's time they started pulling their own weight.
You better tell me the bad news -- it might cheer me up.
I doubt it.
The moment fully clothed females began appearing on the streets of Ferenginar, financial chaos erupted all over the planet.
That explains the communications blackout.
There was so much buying and selling throughout the Alliance that the entire planetary communications grid shut down.
If there's trouble on Ferenginar, what are you doing here?
I've been deposed. I'm no longer Grand Nagus.
Then who is?
Who do you think?
Brunt.
Grand Nagus Brunt?
Acting Grand Nagus Brunt.
Brother -- we're in trouble now. Brunt hates us.
Don't start panicking. The Ferengi Commerce Authority hasn't confirmed him yet.
And they won't for three more days.
Boys, together we're going to reconquer an empire. Or die in the attempt.
What lovely quarters you have, Quark. Small, but lovely.
As of this moment, I declare this site to be the headquarters of the sole legitimate government of Ferenginar.
I still can't believe Brunt is the new Nagus.
Acting Nagus.
For three more days. Then it becomes official.
I'm not worried. I have a secret weapon.
Your mother. Now listen closely -- one, we contact every F.C.A. Commissioner and invite them to the station for a meeting. Two, Ishka runs the meeting.
They'll love that.

Maybe not at first, but she'll win them over. Using her vast financial knowledge and keen instinct for profit, she'll prove -- once and for all -- that allowing females to wear clothing is the first step toward a healthier and more prosperous Ferengi economy. And three... What was three again, my dear?
The F.C.A. Commissioners reinstate you as Nagus.
And you can't ask for a happier ending than that.

But that's only the beginning, lobekins. I predict that one day, a female will enter the Tower of Commerce, climb the forty flights of stairs to the Chamber of Opportunity, and take her rightful place as Grand Nagus of the Ferengi Alliance.
Don't look at me -- it was your amendment.
Nagus -- you remember my son, Nog, don't you? He's the first Ferengi to join Starfleet.
I'll try not to hold that against him.
And this is my wife, Leeta.
I've heard so much about you.
Would you like to hear more?
Remember -- she's Rom's wife.
Meaning what?
Meaning she's broke.
She doesn't look broke to me.
Zekkie...

Just having a little harmless fun, my sweet. Quark, you and your brother, get rid of some of this furniture. You, get three subspace transceivers off my ship and set them up in here. And where's my beetle snuff?
Grand Nagus Brunt... baaah!
Good afternoon, I'm calling on behalf of Grand Nagus Zek...
The Nagus summons you to a meeting here on Deep Space Nine...
He's counting on your support.
You'll be presented with some very interesting financial data...
... there's profit to be earned...
... and the Nagus wants you to share in these lucrative opportunities...
Yes, I'm talking about the Grand Nagus --
No, not Brunt --
-- Grand Nagus Zek.
Who said he was dead?
Wait -- don't end the transmission!
Hello? Hello? Where'd he go?
I'm calling on behalf of Grand Nagus Zek --
I know all about the ninety-fourth Rule of Acquisition --
I know... "Females and finances don't mix," but that can be interpreted in many different ways...
Hello? Hello?
That's not a very nice thing to say about the Nagus.
I beg your pardon!
There's no need to be insulting.
Hello? Hello?
That female happens to be my mother!
Hello? Hello?
Hello? Hello?
Hello? Hello?
Are you sure you contacted every Commissioner on this list?
All four hundred and thirty-two of them.
And you could only convince one of them to attend the meeting?
Maybe if we made some follow-up calls...
I helped every one of those people earn a fortune -- and this is how they repay me?
What a bunch of ingrates.
The news isn't all bad.
The Commissioner who's agreed to come... it's Nilva.
The Chairman of Slug-o-Cola?
He's a very influential voice within the F.C.A.
Unfortunately, he's a very influential voice for the status quo.
I don't think Slug-o-Cola has changed their advertising slogan in three hundred years.
"Drink Slug-o-Cola -- the slimiest cola in the galaxy."
Why would Nilva agree to come to the meeting?
I don't know. But if I can convince him to support Zek, other Commissioners might follow.
It's a start.
See? I told you it was too early to panic.
Care to place a wager on that?
Grand Nagus Brunt...
Acting Grand Nagus Brunt.
Now you can panic.
I'll take an Eelwasser. No ice.
What're you doing here, Brunt?
That's Grand Nagus Brunt.
Acting Grand Nagus.
Would someone please tell that female to take off those clothes -- it's disgusting.
Get used to it, limp lobes. This is the future.
Over my dead body.
If that's what it takes.
I don't suppose you're here to reminisce about the time you helped my brother and I rescue Moogie from the Dominion.
You're right. That's not why I'm here. Though I do find it ironic that helping to rescue your mother was the first step on my road to becoming Nagus.
Don't remind me.
I never should've given you your job back with t'he F.C.A.
But you did. And as a Liquidator, I was able to bribe my way back into a position of power.
That is ironic.
Face it, Zek, it's over. You're finished. Bankrupt. I'm going to liquidate you.

Cancel that Eelwasser and get me a Slug-o-Cola instead. On second thought, I'll just wait for Chairman Nilva to get here. I'm sure he'll be happy to provide his new Nagus with all the Slug-o- Cola I can drink.
How did you know Nilva was coming here?
Because it's my business to know. Go ahead, have your little "meeting." Whatever you offer Nilva, I'll double it.
That's it. Get out of my bar.
You dare to threaten your Nagus.
Acting Nagus. You may liquidate us tomorrow, but right now, this is still my establishment. Now get out before I kick you out.
I'm going to make you a pauper.
Out.
Uri'lash. We're leaving. Say good-bye to all these poor people.
My boy, I'm proud of you.
So am I.
Me, too.
I just threw the Grand Nagus out of my bar.
Acting Grand Nagus.
Whatever. I need to lie down.
You busy, Quark?
Busy? Me? Nah. I'm just lying here wondering if it's not too late for me to start a new life somewhere.
Oh, Quark, there's nothing wrong with your life. Come on, on your feet. Zekkie's waiting for you at the bar.
. Now what?
He feels like playing a game of tongo.
We're all facing banishment from Ferengi society and he wants to play tongo?
He wants to play tongo, I want to have a late night snack, you want to lie here feeling sorry for yourself -- we all deal with stress in different ways. Any fresh tube grubs around?
Any fresh tube grubs around?
How can you eat at a time like this?
It's simple. You put one end of the tube grub between your front teeth, and suck 'em right up.
You want tube grubs? Fine.
Here. Enjoy.
These are minced. I wanted fresh.
You know this is all your fault.
It's my fault you don't have fresh tube grubs?
I'm not talking about tube grubs. I'm talking about Ferengi females wearing clothes and earning profit. I'm talking about Grand Nagus Brunt.
Acting Grand Nagus Brunt.

You're not fooling me, Moogie. You've been plotting this all along. Ever since you met Zek, you've been working on him. Manipulating him. Whispering things in his ear... things like -- -- "equality for females."
What's wrong with that?
I'll tell you what's wrong -- you've ruined Zek's life, your life, Rom's life --
As if you cared about any of us. It's your life you're worried about.
You bet I'm worried. No one else seems to care what happens to me! You come here to my station, take over my quarters, make me a part of your subversive schemes --
What's the matter, Quark? Afraid you've picked the wrong side? You can always go crawling to Brunt -- beg his forgiveness.
I don't want anything to do with Brunt. I want my old Nagus back... I want Zek to be the way he used to be -- before he met you... before you twisted his thinking with your feminine wiles.
Before he met me, Zek was a lonely, unhappy man.

But he was rich. He was the most powerful Ferengi alive. Now what is he? A puppet. And you're the one pulling his strings. Making him dance to your evil, feminist tune. You're the worst thing that ever happened to him. You're the worst thing that ever happened to me. In fact, you're the worst thing that ever happened to the entire Ferengi Alliance.
Maybe I am, but at least I'm not like you. A selfish, spineless, ungrateful...
Is that the best you can do?
You are... you are... you really are... you... you... you...
Go ahead and say it!
You...
Moogie?
Moogie? Uh-oh.
Moogie... please don't die.
I hope so. For her sake, for my sake, for the sake of the entire Ferengi Alliance...
... but most of all, I hope she gets better for your sake, Quark. Because if she doesn't...
What did I do?
That's exactly the question I keep asking myself -- what did you do to her?
I told you, she said she was hungry and I gave her some tube grubs. She thanked me then she collapsed. I wish you'd stop making me relive it.
Are you sure you didn't do or say anything that might've upset her?
I don't want to talk about it anymore.
What's the matter, Quark? Your conscience bothering you?
I haven't done anything wrong!
That's not what your mother says.
Doctor, how's Moogie?
Will she live?
She'll live. She needed a new heart and it's functioning normally. But she's going to need complete rest for a few days. And that means keeping her far away from him.
And why is that, doctor?
I'm not sure exactly. All I know is that Ishka keeps repeating the same phrase over and over -- "It's all Quark's fault. It's all Quark's fault."
I wonder what she means by that?

... and then I accused her of being the worst thing that ever happened to the Ferengi Alliance and she clutched her chest and collapsed. Moogie and I argue all the time -- it's our way of showing affection.
Well, if you ask me, Quark -- the worst thing that ever happened to the Ferengi Alliance is you.
I'm sorry.
I suppose we should contact Nilva and tell him the meeting has to be postponed.
We can't postpone the meeting. In two days, the F.C.A. is going to confirm Brunt as the new Grand Nagus.
Boy, when things go wrong...
... the only thing to do is get down on your knees and beg for mercy.
Who knows? You might find me in a charitable mood.
By the time I'm through with you, you're the one who's going to need charity.
Such brave words, yet so empty. I was very relieved to hear that your mother is going to be all right.
Of course, that's not going to do you much good. Nilva will be arriving tonight expecting to meet a "brilliant" Ferengi female. Do you know any -- I mean besides Ishka? I certainly don't.
How pitiful. One day you're the Grand Nagus of the Ferengi Alliance, the next you're nothing but a common barroom brawler. See what happens when you put your faith in a female?
What about Leeta?
What about her?
Maybe she can meet with Nilva. She handles my finances and she's a female.
And a very beautiful one at that. But Nilva's expecting to meet with a Ferengi female.
We'll never get one here in time.
We're doomed.
No, we're not. You think Ishka would give up if she were here?
If she were here, we wouldn't have a problem.
That's not the point. Your mother would never accept defeat. If she couldn't find another female, she'd... she'd... she'd...
She'd what?
She'd make one!
You mean a hologram?
Better than a hologram.
What could be better than a hologram?
You.
He's been in there an awfully long time.
It's a delicate procedure.
I'll say.
Doctor -- what is it? Did something go wrong?
That depends how you look at it.
The operation -- was it a success?
I suppose you could say that.
That's good.
I hope so.
You can come out now.
Brother, you look... beautiful.
He's a little emotional... his endocrine system needs some time to adjust to its new hormonal balance.
He'll be all right in a few minutes. Now if you'll excuse me, I have to go figure out how I'm going to enter this into my medical log.
Does anyone have a handkerchief?
Where are my clothes? I want to go back to my quarters.
Try this on.
Must be the wrong size.
Oww! That hurts.
Oh, don't be such a baby. They're just earrings.
They're heavy.
You'll get used to them.
I hope not.
Would you stop doing that.
Doing what?
Looking down. Now hold still, I'm almost done. There.
How do I look?
You look... nice.
Nice? That's all?
Very nice.
You may look like a female but you've got to do something about that voice.
I'm trying. I mean I'm trying.
Well, try harder.
And stop looking down.
I need to see what I look like. Someone get me a mirror.
You see, brother? You're lovely.
There go his hormones again.
You mean, her hormones.
Take it away, take it away.
I'm sorry. It's just that I feel so... ... different..
Would you stop staring at your chest.
I wasn't staring at my chest -- I was staring at my hips. Aren't they too big?
Your hips are fine. Now let's get down to business.
These are your mother's notes for her meeting with Nilva. Study them carefully.
"Female apparel -- a new source of latinum for a new Ferenginar."
"Hypicate cream -- for smooth skin and healthier profits."
All these facts and figures... it's too much to remember.
Nonsense. You just need a little time to practice your presentation.
And while you're at it, you need to practice your walk.
What's wrong with my walk?
You're lumbering.
This is never going to work.
Don't cry, Brother. Here, let me show you. Watch carefully.
You see? It's more of a glide.
That's good.
And when you sit -- be sure your knees are touching. And don't forget to relax your shoulders, but keep your bottom tight.
What?
He's the one who should be wearing the dress.
Why me?
You're so adorable... and complicated.
Maybe it's not too late. Come on, I'll take you to Doctor Bashir --
Forget it, Quark. Rom may make a better female than you, but when it comes to business, you're the better Ferengi.
Looks like your stupidity has saved you again.
It comes in handy sometimes.
(trying to convince himself) I can do this... its only for one meeting. I can be a female for one meeting.
Can't I?
Not if you're lumbering.
I'll conduct the meeting sitting down.
Tighten your bottom.
I think you're doing wonderfully, my dear. I'm proud of you.
Sorry. You may walk like a man, but you make a very attractive female. Confusing, isn't it?
Not to me.
He's here -- he's on the station!
Who is?
Nilva.
But he's not supposed to arrive until tomorrow.
That Nilva. He's a tricky one. But he makes a good cola.
What do we do?
I can't meet Nilva now, I'm still lumbering.
You look very nice.
Nog, I want you to escort the chairman to his quarters. Tell him I'll meet him for dinner tonight.
What if he asks about Ishka?
Tell him that Ishka is sick, but that tomorrow he'll be meeting with my other female financial advisor... ...Lumba.
Right.
Lumba?
You'd better start memorizing those notes.
First, we need to practice your walking.
And your sitting.
And don't forget to work on that voice.
Any other comments?
Has anyone ever told you that you have lovely eyes?
Welcome to Deep Space Nine, Chairman Nilva.
Here. Have a Slug-o-Cola.
You drink Slug-o-Cola, don't you?
The slimiest cola in the galaxy? Doesn't everybody?
Good boy. Now take me to Zek.
But Zek wanted me to --
Don't argue with me. Just drink your cola and lead the way.
You sure you don't want to stop by your quarters and freshen up?
Not before I meet this female advisor of Zek's.
Nilva! How nice to see you again.
Grand Nagus Brunt.
Acting Grand Nagus Brunt.
I had a feeling I might find you here.
I thought after your meeting with Zek, we could have a little chat.
Of course. But I've really come to meet this... Ishka female.
Haven't you heard? Ishka's in the Infirmary. She's in no position to meet anyone.
Which is why you'll be meeting with another one of Zek's financial advisors. Her name is Lumba.
Never heard of her.
Zek has two female advisors?
I didn't know there were two Ferengi females on the station.
Well, what are we waiting for? Let's go meet this "other" female.
You're sure you wouldn't like me to show you around the station first?
I want to meet Lumba.
Lumba?
All right, let's try it again.
My name is Lumba. You must be Chairman Nilva. Zek's told me so much about you...
What's wrong now?
These earrings -- they're killing me. Do I have to wear them?
No woman is complete without earrings.
Why does everyone keep looking at me?
I'm going to bed.
Now?
I'm exhausted. I've got to get some sleep or I'll never make it through tomorrow's meeting.
Who could that be?
Come in.
Nilva!
Zek. Have a Slug-o-Cola. Don't worry, I brought enough for everyone.
He insisted on seeing you immediately.
You must be Lunga.
Lumba.

Of course. (looking Quark up and down) A Ferengi female wearing clothes -- -- and with your approval, no less. You've either been inhaling too much beetle snuff or you're the greatest visionary to ever sit atop the Tower of Commerce.
Well, why don't you and I have dinner tonight and try to figure it out. We can go to Quark's and get some nice, juicy snail steaks. You can meet with Lumba tomorrow.

I'm afraid that's not possible. I have to leave first thing in the morning. I'm due to attend an important stockholders meeting back on Ferenginar. But snail steaks do sound tempting. Why don't I have dinner with Lumba?
With me?
(trying to derail this train) Won't you feel uncomfortable being seen in public with a clothed female?

Of course I will. But you and I have made a lot of latinum together over the years... I suppose that's worth a little discomfort. But Lumba better be all you claim she is or I'll liquidate you myself. Let's eat.
Have fun.
(misinterpreting all the attention) See how everyone's staring? Even aliens find a clothed Ferengi female shocking.
Two snail steaks, lightly seared.
Tell me something, doesn't wearing all those clothes make you feel like a deviant?
Not really. And you know why? Because under all these clothes, I'm totally naked.
I'll try to remember that. Now, perhaps you'd better explain to me how allowing females to wear clothing is going to make me richer than I already am.
I was hoping you were going to ask me that. You see this dress I'm wearing? Have you any idea how much it would sell for on Ferenginar?
Would someone please tell me what they're saying.
Shhh.
... let me see if I understand. Giving females the right to wear clothes allows them to have pockets. Once they have pockets, they're going to want to fill them with latinum.
Which means they're going to need jobs.
And once they start earning latinum, they're going to want to spend it.
Which means Ferenginar will be expanding its work force and its consumer base at the same time.
That way there'll be profit for everyone.
When it comes to profit, I'm your girl.
And I'm sure you could use some extra latinum.
Meaning what?
I read the beverage trades. Sales of Slug-o-Cola have flattened out, while Eelwasser had a very impressive third quarter.
They got lucky, that's all.
I know a way you can increase Slug- o-Cola sales by fifty to sixty percent.
(leaning forward; intrigued) I'm all ears.
Target the new female consumer. Make Slug-o-Cola her drink.
Nothing's stopping her from drinking it now.
But you're not encouraging her either. "The slimiest cola in the galaxy." That kind of slogan doesn't appeal to women.
And what would?
Let me see... Slug-o-Cola contains forty-three percent live algae, right?
In every bottle.
Well, how about something like... "Drink Slug-o-Cola and keep your teeth a sparkling shade of green."
Zek was right about you. You're very intelligent.
You mean for a female?
I think it's time for dessert.
Good idea.
I thought we were going to have dessert?
We are. In my quarters.
Come in, come in. It's so good not to be stared at. Although I must admit, I did find it somewhat... stimulating.
You know the Replimat has very tasty desserts.
Not as tasty as the one I have in mind. You have the most delicate little lobes. I think I'll start with them.
I never thought I'd find a clothed female so enticing.
I'm not that enticing. What you need is a good night's sleep.
A little oo-mox and I'll sleep like a baby.
I hear the station has some very nice holosuites...
I don't like holosuites.
Chairman Nilva! What's gotten into you?
It's my wife. She hasn't touched my lobes in months!
I'm sorry to hear that. Maybe she's bored -- she probably needs to get out more.
I don't want to talk about her. In fact, I don't want to talk at all.
My lobes burn for you. If you don't believe me, touch them.
I'll take your word for it.
You said you'd do anything for me!
I lied.
But I need you!
No, you don't!
Come to me, my little love slave.
Let go of that man!
I'm trying.
Would you please leave. You're making Lumba nervous.
His name's not Lumba, it's Quark! And he's a male.
A male?
How pitiful. Zek must be truly desperate.
(to Quark, clearly disappointed) Is this true? You're a man?
Do I look like a man?
Nice try, Quark. But it's not going to work. I tell you, he's the station's bartender.
Don't believe him, hot lobes. I'm as female as they come and I'll prove it to you.
Well?
I'm not sure...
Oh, all right...
Now are you sure?
Completely.
I tell you -- that is not a female!
She's close enough for me.
Come, my dear, let's go tell Zek that I'm going to do everything in my power to see that he remains Grand Nagus.
But why?
Because that's what Lumba wants.
His name's Quark!
What's in a name?
What can I say? It was love at first sight.
Interesting ring.
It was a gift. Poor Nilva. He's such a lovely man, but so lonely.
Really?
There's a sweetness to him. And a strength. Sometimes he gets this little glint in his eye...
You know what I mean...
Not really, but I'm glad you had a pleasant evening.
You're mocking me, aren't you?
And you're being a little oversensitive.
I've only been male again for six hours. My hormones must still be out of balance. My emotions are raging out of control.
Is there anything I can do?
Would you mind giving me a hug?
A hug?
Just a small one.
(his head buried in Odo's shoulder) Thank you.
I hope we're not interrupting anything.
We just wanted to say good-bye before we go back to Ferenginar.
Where the rivers run with muck and the streets are swarming with happy females.
And where, if everything goes according to plan, the F.C.A. commissioners will once again proclaim me Grand Nagus.
That would be nice. But Brunt's going to fight you at every turn.
I wouldn't have it any other way.
I'm glad we have Nilva on our side. And we have you to thank for that, Quark.
Then you forgive me, Moogie?
Of course I do. You may be a lousy son, but you made a wonderful daughter. I hope the experience taught you something.
It's made me more compassionate... empathetic... nurturing.
I feel like I'm trapped in my worst nightmare.
Don't worry. I'm sure it won't last. You'll be back to your old self in no time.
You're so lucky. No man ever gave me a ring.
Colonel.
(smiling in spite of herself) Odo, I wish you'd stop doing that.
Doing what?
Calling me by my rank. I was promoted two months ago. Besides, it sounds so... formal.
Has Admiral Ross -- or should I say Bill -- arrived yet?
The admiral's ship is due to arrive in three hours. I wish I knew what he wants to see me about.
Maybe he's bringing good news. We could certainly use some.
Don't get your hopes up. There was something in the tone of his voice...
Something ominous?
Something... pleasant. He was going out of his way to be nice...
I see...
Whatever he's coming to tell me, he knows I'm not going to like it.
How can you be so sure?
It comes with the job.
I'm serious. Sitting in the Captain's Chair, having that kind of responsibility... it focuses you...
I'll take your word for it.
(with growing frustration) How many days have they been sitting there?
Three.
I can remember when the cult of the Pah-wraiths was considered a joke... now those red armbands are appearing all over Bajor. It's like everyone's gone crazy.
A lot of people feel abandoned by the Prophets...
Believe me, I know how they feel. But that's no excuse to turn to hate and fear.
In times of trouble, some people find comfort in hate and fear. (re: the supplicants)
If you'd like, I can charge them with loitering and have them removed from the station.
What good would that do? I keep thinking... if the Emissary were here, things might be different.
I would've thought we'd have heard from Captain Sisko by now.
Not a word in three months.
I realize things may seem bleak at the moment, but there's always hope...
Since when did you become such an optimist?
Must have been that day, in front of Quark's, when we kissed for the first time.
That was some kiss, wasn't it?
Changed my life.
Gentlemen, we are home.
There should be a law against convoy duty lasting more than ten days.
I'll say one thing for guarding convoys -- it's usually a lot safer than being on the front lines.
Is that why you joined Starfleet, ensign? To be safe?
I didn't mean that the way it sounded, sir...
In wartime, it's a soldier's duty to fight.
Yes, sir.

The invasion of Cardassia has ground to a halt while our casualties continue to mount. It is a time for warriors to do great deeds. To triumph in glorious battle -- not waste away protecting shipments of stembolts!
I hope Commander Worf doesn't think I'm afraid to fight.
Relax, Nog. Don't take it so personally -- Worf's just going through a hard time.
He needs to focus on something other than Jadzia. I hate to admit it, but combat duty just might do the trick.
The Defiant will be going into battle soon enough. Then Worf can be happy and the rest of us can be miserable.
It's not that I'm afraid to fight... it's just that I don't want to die. I wish Captain Sisko were here.
So do I, ensign. So do I.
(to the first customer) If I were you, I'd order the crawfish etoufee. (to the second customer) And if it's good enough for him, it's good enough for you.
I think table five is ready to order.
He's been at that piano since seven o'clock this morning.
Customers seem to like it.
Grandpa...
I'm worried too, but he's got something to work out... best we leave him alone.
We've left him alone for three months! He said he came here to figure out a way to contact the Prophets... to make things right. But so far he hasn't even left the restaurant.
Dad? What is it? What's wrong?
Dad!
I had a vision... from the Prophets. I was on Tyree, in the desert... digging in the sand... I uncovered a face... the face of a woman.
And?
That's all...
Who was she?
I've never seen her before... but now I know why I came back here. I have to find her, Jake... I have to.
Colonel, I really don't think you have anything to be concerned about. I've met Senator Cretak and I found her to be... very cooperative.
For a Romulan.
Cretak's a strong supporter of the Alliance... and we need that kind of support if we're going to win this war.
I don't care if the Romulans were the only thing standing between us and total annihilation, I'd still think twice about letting them establish a military presence here on the station.
(with some exasperation) We're just talking about a few offices for the senator and her staff.
And a contingent of personal guards.
A dozen people, at most. Besides, it's only a temporary arrangement -- until the end of the war.
And when will that be?
Let's get one thing straight, colonel. I came here as a courtesy to you. This decision has already been made.
And I have to live with it.
That's right.
You've done a fine job, taking over for Captain Sisko.
I'm just keeping his seat warm.
You still think he'll be back?
Don't you?
I'll be in touch.
As you can see, we've halted the Klingon advance against Monac Four. We estimate their casualties at over thirty percent.
They should've been higher. Nevertheless, congratulations Damar. The enemy remains bottled up within the Chin'toka system. And there they'll stay until we destroy them.
I'd offer you a glass, but I know how much you dislike kanar.
I'm beginning to think you like it too much.
I wouldn't trust a Cardassian who doesn't enjoy a glass of kanar every once in awhile.
Tell me, Damar -- when you're alone, do you even bother with a glass, or do you just drink that swill directly from the bottle?
It depends on my mood. And right now, I feel like celebrating. We owe Gul Dukat a debt of gratitude.
Unfortunately, I agree. Somehow, releasing that Pah-wraith into the wormhole has shifted the momentum of the war in our favor.
Do you ever wonder what's going on in there... the wormhole, I mean.
Not really.
The Prophets and the Pah-wraiths locked in some kind of celestial battle... it's fascinating.
I never realized you had such a vivid imagination.
There's a lot about me you don't know.
Just remember, having too much imagination can be... dangerous.
(trying to engage him) Dad -- Grandpa and I are going over to Armstrong Park to listen to some music. Want to come?
You two go ahead.
What's that?
The woman I saw in my vision... I don't want to forget her face.
I'll see you in the morning.
Hey... I've seen her.
Where?
In a photograph...
Here she is. I knew it.
It's her, isn't it?
I don't understand... who is she?
Why don't you ask Grandpa?
Ask me what?
This woman --
Where'd you get that?
I found it last week when I was cleaning out the storage room. I meant to ask you about it.
Who is she, Dad?
She's no one, you hear me? No one at all.
Hey, pallie -- where you been keeping yourself.
Convoy duty.
Doesn't sound very exciting.
It wasn't.
Well, if you're looking for a little action, you've come to the right place. What do you say we hit the craps tables? Or maybe a little blackjack to get the blood pumping?
Sing the song.
I don't think that's such a good idea...
Sing the song.
C'mon, pallie... why rub salt on an open wound?
You're a hologram. You're programmed to do as I say. Sing the song.
It's your dime, pallie.
Park it right there.
And don't say I didn't warn you. Which reminds me of a story Joey once told me --
(interrupting, a threat) Sing!
(to the band, a la Joey Bishop) Son of a gun, I think he means it.
This monitor is still off-line. I want it operational within the hour.
I hope all the chairs on this station aren't this uncomfortable.
I'm afraid they are.
But don't worry, you'll get used to them.
I'm sure I will. (stands up to greet Kira) You must be Colonel Kira.
I'm sorry I wasn't there to greet you at the airlock when you arrived. I was --
No need to explain, Colonel. I'm sure you're quite busy.
I hope you find your accommodations satisfactory. Other than the chairs, of course.
I'm sure we'll be quite comfortable here. I trust that won't be a problem for you.
Meaning what?
My people have a reputation for arrogance. I'm afraid it's well- earned.
But you're different. Or so Admiral Ross tells me.
The admiral and I have a good working relationship. I hope to have a similar one with you.
I'd like nothing more.
Then I look forward to working with you toward our common goal -- the destruction of the Dominion.
Worf did this?

With his own two hands -- and it's not the first time he's busted up the joint. I don't care how much he threatens me, that's the last time I ever sing "All the Way." If he wants to hear it again, let him buy a Sinatra album.
(putting it all
So am I, but you don't see me "busting up the joint."
She wasn't your wife.
She should've been.
But there is something wrong here...
That's what I've been telling you.
Klingons usually have a much shorter mourning period than humans. They accept death more readily than we do.
Well, something's driving Worf cuckoo. Your buddy needs to get some serious help --
-- and soon. The band's threatening to quit.
They can't quit -- they're holograms.
They don't know that.
I'll see what I can do.
Hang in there, pallie.
I'll try, but I think Jadzia's death has made us all a little cuckoo.
Dad?
You should be in bed.
Not until you tell me what I need to know.
I already told you. She's no one.
You're going to have to do better than that.
Leave it be, Ben.
I can't. I saw her.
That's impossible.
I'm telling you, I saw her.
You couldn't have...
Dad -- please! Who is she?
I'm sorry, but I don't want to talk about it.
Dad --
No!
You have to tell me. I have to know who she is!
Her name was Sarah. I met her in June of '31. (a small smile at the memory) It was in Jackson Square... she was, without a doubt, the most beautiful woman I'd ever seen.
Two months later, we were married.
Married? You had a wife before Mom?
It's a little more complicated than that, Ben. You see... Sarah was your mother.
Sarah and I were married for two years. She seemed... very happy. I certainly was. Two days after your first birthday, she disappeared.
What do you mean she disappeared?
She left me.
